summary: This is a court order from Judge Kenneth A. Marra requesting the United States government to state its position regarding Jeffrey Epstein's motion to stay multiple civil lawsuits against him. Epstein argues that defending the civil cases violates his Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) with the U.S. Attorney's Office and could subject him to criminal prosecution. The order lists numerous Jane Doe plaintiffs who have filed civil cases against Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein

events.title: Court Order Requesting U.S. Position on Stay Motion
events.description: Judge Kenneth A. Marra issues an order requesting the United States government to provide its position on Jeffrey Epstein's motion to stay multiple civil lawsuits against him, based on his claim that defending them violates his Non-Prosecution Agreement.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of Florida
West Palm Beach, Palm Beach County, Florida
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was facing at least 11 separate civil lawsuits from plaintiffs identified as Jane Does and C.M.A. as of May 2009.
Epstein filed a motion to stay the civil cases, arguing that defending them violated his Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) with the U.S. Attorney's Office and could subject him to criminal prosecution.
The court order reveals Epstein's legal strategy of using the NPA to seek delays in civil litigation, claiming the USAO viewed his civil defense as a violation of the agreement.

Judge Kenneth A. Marra formally requested the United States government to state its position on whether Epstein's defense of civil cases violated the NPA, indicating judicial scrutiny of the agreement's implications.
